603.name: Carbonated Water
603.description: Carbonated water is water into which carbon dioxide gas has been dissolved under pressure, resulting in effervescence. It is commonly used as a base for soft drinks and in sparkling waters.

sources.label: PubMed â Erosive potential of different beverages in relation to enamel softening
PMC6026745 â Effects and safety of carbonated water consumption

603.risks: Dental erosion with excessive consumption, mild gastrointestinal discomfort in sensitive individuals

566.name: Organic flavors
566.description: Organic flavors are flavoring agents derived from certified organic sources but still undergo chemical extraction and processing similarly to conventional natural flavors. The exact composition is typically not disclosed, and they serve only to enhance taste without contributing nutritional value.

sources.label: PMC8026810 â Health implications of flavor additives
PubMed â Natural and organic flavorings: food safety perspectives

566.risks: Lack of transparency, ultra-processed, may contain organic solvents or carriers, no nutritional value

42.name: Magnesium
42.description: Magnesium is an essential mineral involved in over 300 enzymatic reactions in the body, supporting muscle function, nerve transmission, energy production, and bone health.

sources.label: NIH Office of Dietary Supplements â Magnesium Fact Sheet
PubMed â Dietary magnesium and cardiovascular disease

42.risks: Diarrhea at high doses, gastrointestinal upset, risk of toxicity in renal impairment
42.benefits: Supports energy metabolism, improves muscle and nerve function, promotes bone health, helps regulate blood pressure, may reduce risk of type 2 diabetes, supports cardiovascular health

659.name: Hydrogen
659.description: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe, often found bound to other elements, most notably as H2O (water). As a food ingredient, it typically refers to hydrogen gas dissolved in water (hydrogen water), promoted for potential antioxidant effects.

sources.label: PMC5783776 â Effects and mechanisms of hydrogen-rich water on health
PubMed â Molecular hydrogen as a novel anti-inflammatory agent

659.benefits: Possible antioxidant effects, may help reduce oxidative stress, potential anti-inflammatory properties

20.name: Arsenic
20.description: Arsenic is a naturally occurring element found in the earthâs crust, but inorganic arsenic compounds are highly toxic and classified as human carcinogens, posing significant health risks when present in food or water.

sources.label: PMC4144270 â Health effects of arsenic exposure
PubMed â Arsenic Toxicity and Human Health
EWG Gidelines

20.risks: Carcinogenic, neurotoxic, increased risk of cardiovascular disease, skin lesions, reproductive toxicity, increased risk of diabetes, developmental effects

21.name: Barium
21.description: A naturally occurring element often derived from industrial discharges and natural deposits

sources.label: Kravchenko J, Darrah TH, Miller RK, Lyerly HK, Vengosh A. A review of the health impacts of barium from natural and anthropogenic exposure. Environ Geochem Health. 2014 Aug
ToxFAQsâ¢ for Barium
Get Informed | Barium

21.risks: Can lead to increased blood pressure, heart and nervous system problems, and long-term exposure may cause severe health effects like kidney damage and impacts on other organs.

77.name: Boron
77.description: Boron is a trace mineral naturally found in foods and the environment, known to play a role in bone health, cognitive function, and the metabolism of other minerals such as calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus.

sources.label: PMC4712861 â The Influence of Boron on Health
PubMed â Boron in human health: Evidence for dietary recommendation

77.risks: Potential toxicity at high doses, gastrointestinal upset at excessive intake, unknown long-term safety of supplements
77.benefits: Supports bone health, regulates inflammatory response, assists in mineral metabolism, may benefit cognitive function

41.name: Calcium
41.description: Calcium is an essential mineral that plays a critical role in bone health, muscle contraction, nerve signaling, and cellular function. In food products, it is often added as a fortificant to improve nutritional profile.

sources.label: PMC6164457 â Calcium in Human Health
PubMed â Calcium and bone health

41.risks: Hypercalcemia from excessive intake, possible kidney stone formation, interference with absorption of other minerals at high doses
41.benefits: Supports bone health, essential for muscle function, vital for nerve transmission, important for cardiovascular health

82.name: Iron
82.description: Iron is an essential mineral required for oxygen transport in the blood, energy metabolism, and immune function. It is commonly added to foods and supplements to prevent or treat iron deficiency anemia.

sources.label: PMC â Iron metabolism and supplementation
PubMed â Benefits and adverse effects of iron

82.risks: Gastrointestinal upset, constipation, iron overload with excessive intake, harmful for individuals with hemochromatosis
82.benefits: Prevents iron deficiency anemia, supports cognitive development, essential for oxygen transport, supports immune function

46.name: Manganese
46.description: Manganese is an essential trace mineral involved in bone formation, amino acid, carbohydrate, and cholesterol metabolism, and antioxidant defense in the human body.

sources.label: NIH Fact Sheet: Manganese
PubMed â Manganese in health and disease

46.risks: Neurotoxicity at high doses, possible increased risk of cognitive impairment with excessive supplementation, accumulation risk in those with liver dysfunction
46.benefits: Essential for enzyme function, bone health, antioxidant defense, metabolism of nutrients

43.name: Potassium
43.description: Potassium is an essential dietary mineral and electrolyte involved in nerve transmission, muscle contraction, fluid balance, and regulating blood pressure.

sources.label: PMC8360998 â Potassium intake and cardiovascular health
PubMed â Effects of dietary potassium on health

43.risks: Hyperkalemia in cases of kidney dysfunction, possible arrhythmias with excessive supplementation
43.benefits: Supports cardiovascular health, helps regulate blood pressure, essential for nerve and muscle function, reduces risk of stroke

45.name: Sodium
45.description: Sodium is an essential mineral and electrolyte required for nerve function, muscle contraction, and fluid balance in the body. In food products, it is most often present as sodium chloride (table salt) and used for flavoring and preservation.

sources.label: PubMed â Adverse effects of excessive sodium consumption
PMC6769760 â Dietary sodium, cardiovascular disease, and health

45.risks: High blood pressure, increased risk of cardiovascular disease, kidney strain, potential for fluid retention
45.benefits: Essential electrolyte, supports nerve function, maintains fluid balance

8.name: Bromide
8.description: When bromide reacts with ozone, it can form bromate, which can have adverse health effects on the kidneys. When bromide reacts with chlorine and naturally occurring organic matter, it can form byproducts like trihalomethanes (THMs) and halogenated acetic acids (HAAs)

sources.label: Gonsioroski A, Mourikes VE, Flaws JA. Endocrine Disruptors in Water and Their Effects on the Reproductive System. International Journal of Molecular Sciences. 2020

Alomirah HF, Al-Zenki SF, Alaswad MC, Alruwaih NA, Wu Q, Kannan K. Elevated concentrations of bromate in Drinking water and groundwater from Kuwait and associated exposure and health risks. Environ Res. 2020 Feb
Get Informed | Bromide

8.risks: At very high doses, bromide can cause neurological effects

22.name: Fluoride
22.description: A mineral known for its dental health benefits.

sources.label: Impact of Drinking Water Fluoride on Human Thyroid Hormones
Endocrine Disruptors in Water and Their Effects on the Reproductive System
Water Fluoridation: A Critical Review of the Physiological Effects of Ingested Fluoride as a Public Health Intervention
Community Water Fluoridation Levels To Promote Effectiveness and Safety in Oral Health â United States, 2016â2021
U.S. Public Health Service Recommendation for Fluoride Concentration in Drinking Water for the Prevention of Dental Caries
Fluoride
Guidelines for Canadian Drinking Water Quality
WHO - Fluoride in Drinking Water

22.risks: Can cause dental and skeletal fluorosis, affecting teeth and bone health, and may potentially impact cognitive development in children.
22.benefits: Strengthens tooth enamel, reduces dental cavities, and aids in remineralizing teeth, enhancing overall oral health.

17.name: Silica
17.description: Silica, also known as silicon dioxide, is a naturally occurring mineral commonly used in food products as an anti-caking agent to prevent clumping. It does not provide nutritional value and is largely inert in the digestive tract.

sources.label: PMC4997433 - Silicon dioxide as a food additive
PubMed - Safety of synthetic amorphous silica as a food additive

17.risks: None at typical food additive levels, inhalation risk for workers handling powder form

513.name: Natural flavors
513.description: âNatural flavorsâ is a regulatory term defined by the FDA that refers to flavoring agents derived from plant or animal sources. These ingredients are often further processed using solvents, carriers, and other additives. The specific composition is not disclosed on labels and may include multiple subcomponents. Natural flavors are considered Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) by the U.S. FDA, though their formulations are proprietary and not individually disclosed.

sources.label: PMC8026810 â Health implications of flavor additives
PubMed â Risk factors in food flavoring components
FDA Natural Flavor Regulation

513.risks: Lack of transparency, may contain solvents or preservatives, ultra-processed, risk of allergic reactions, no nutritional value

80.name: Antimony
80.description: Primarily occurs as antimony(V) or antimony(III) ions, depending on the water's pH and redox conditions

sources.label: EWG - Antimony
Cooper RG, Harrison AP. The exposure to and health effects of antimony. Indian J Occup Environ Med. 2009 Apr;13

80.risks: Respiratory irritation, skin problems, and more severe effects such as cardiovascular and lung diseases.
80.benefits: Not known to have any beneficial biological role; in fact, it is not required by the human body.

9.name: Chloride
9.description: Chloride is an essential electrolyte and mineral found naturally in many foods, commonly present in table salt (sodium chloride). It plays a critical role in maintaining fluid balance, transmitting nerve impulses, and supporting proper muscle function in the body.

sources.label: NCBI Bookshelf â Physiology, Chloride
PubMed â Chloride: Physiology and Clinical Application

9.risks: Electrolyte imbalance if consumed in excess, may contribute to hypertension when paired with sodium
9.benefits: Essential electrolyte, supports fluid balance, supports nervous system function, supports muscle function

166.name: Chromium
166.description: Chromium is an essential trace mineral involved in carbohydrate, lipid, and protein metabolism, and it enhances the action of insulin in the body.

sources.label: NIH: Chromium Fact Sheet for Health Professionals
PubMed â Chromium supplementation in human health, particularly in diabetes

166.risks: Potential toxicity at high doses, possible kidney or liver damage with excessive supplementation, limited evidence for benefits in healthy individuals
166.benefits: May improve glycemic control in type 2 diabetes, supports normal macronutrient metabolism

58.name: Nickel
58.description: Nickel is a naturally occurring metal sometimes found as a contaminant in food or water, and it can be intentionally added in trace amounts for dietary purposes, though it is not considered essential for humans.

sources.label: PMC6682823 â Nickel in Human Health and the Environment
PubMed â Nickel: Human Health and Toxicity

58.risks: Allergic reactions, contact dermatitis, gastrointestinal irritation, potential carcinogenicity at high exposures, accumulation with chronic intake

10.name: Sulfate
10.description: Sulfates can be naturally occurring in drinking water and can have both positive and negative health implications. This overview provides a concise summary of these aspects.

sources.label: Research Advances in Identifying Sulfate Contamination Sources of Water Environment by Using Stable Isotopes
Sulfate In Well Water
Sulfate & Health - California Air Resources Board - CA

10.risks: Can cause diarrhea, especially in infants and unaccustomed individuals, pose risks to susceptible populations, and are subject to ongoing regulatory evaluation due to potential health effects.
10.benefits: In moderate amounts, sulfates may facilitate the absorption of certain nutrients and aid digestion.

40.name: Bromate
40.description: A carcinogenic disinfection by-product formed when water containing bromide is treated. Studies of laboratory animals have shown that bromate can damage DNA and causes cancer in organs.

sources.label: Bromate in Drinking Water - New York Department of Health

Alomirah HF, Al-Zenki SF, Alaswad MC, Alruwaih NA, Wu Q, Kannan K. Elevated concentrations of bromate in Drinking water and groundwater from Kuwait and associated exposure and health risks. Environ Res. 2020 Feb
Modes of Action for Bromate-Induced Health Effects
Analysis of Cumulative Cancer Risk Associated with Disinfection Byproducts in United States Drinking Water
Critical Review on Bromate Formation during Ozonation and Control Options for Its Minimization

40.risks: Associated with an increased risk of cancer, particularly thyroid and kidney cancers

1.name: Calcium Chloride
1.description: Calcium chloride is a mineral salt used as a firming agent, preservative, or electrolyte in food processing. In the body, it provides calcium ions important for bone health, nerve transmission, and heart function, though the amounts in foods are generally small.

sources.label: PubMed â Calcium chloride as a food additive: Safety evaluation
NCBI Bookshelf â Calcium Chloride

1.risks: Possible gastrointestinal irritation at high doses, mild saltiness or bitterness, minimal nutritional value in typical food additive amounts
1.benefits: Source of calcium, stabilizes texture in canned vegetables and cheeses

5.name: Sodium Bicarbonate
5.description: Sodium bicarbonate, also known as baking soda, is a leavening agent commonly used in baking and a pH buffer in food products. In the body, it acts to neutralize acids and is sometimes used therapeutically to correct metabolic acidosis.

sources.label: PubMed â Use of sodium bicarbonate in exercise performance
NCBI Bookshelf â Sodium Bicarbonate

5.risks: Excess sodium intake, alkalosis with high doses, gastrointestinal upset
5.benefits: Leavening agent, acid neutralizer, may improve short-term athletic performance by buffering lactic acid

23.name: Nitrate
23.description: A compound often originating from agricultural runoff, sewage, and decaying organic matter.

sources.label: Lin, L., St Clair, S., Gamble, G.D. et al. Nitrate contamination in drinking water and adverse reproductive and birth outcomes: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Sci Rep 13
Ward MH, Jones RR, Brender JD, de Kok TM, Weyer PJ, Nolan BT, Villanueva CM, van Breda SG. Drinking Water Nitrate and Human Health: An Updated Review. Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2018 Jul
Nitrate in Drinking Water

23.risks: High levels of nitrate in drinking water can cause methemoglobinemia, or "blue baby syndrome," in infants, a condition that reduces the blood's ability to carry oxygen . Long-term exposure to elevated nitrate levels has been associated with an increased risk of certain cancers, thyroid dysfunction, and potential reproductive issues .â
23.benefits: In moderate amounts, dietary nitratesâespecially from vegetables like spinach and beetsâcan convert to nitric oxide in the body, aiding in blood pressure regulation and cardiovascular health

15.name: Gross Beta
15.description: Measures the total beta radiation emitted by all beta-emitting radionuclides in a water sample, such as strontium-90 and cesium-137, to evaluate overall beta radiation levels.
15.risks: Internal tissue damage, increased cancer risk, and potential harm to the thyroid.

26.name: Bicarbonate Alkalinity (as HCO3)
26.description: Bicarbonate alkalinity refers to the concentration of bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) present in water, which act as a buffer to maintain stable pH levels. It plays an important role in regulating acid-base balance in both environmental and physiological contexts.

sources.label: PubMed â The role of bicarbonate in acid-base homeostasis
PMC â Bicarbonate therapy in clinical medicine

26.risks: Can contribute to high sodium intake when combined with sodium, rare risk of alkalosis in patients with impaired kidney function
26.benefits: Helps buffer blood pH, supports acid-base homeostasis, may reduce risk of kidney stones in certain populations

69.name: PFAS
69.description: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are a group of man-made chemicals that have been widely used in various industries since the 1940s. PFAS are often found in water due to their extensive use in products like non-stick cookware, water-repellent clothing, and firefighting foams, and their resistance to degradation.

sources.label: Nicole W. PFOA and cancer in a highly exposed community: new findings from the C8 science panel. Environ Health Perspect. 2013 Nov-Dec

Fenton SE, Ducatman A, Boobis A, DeWitt JC, Lau C, Ng C, Smith JS, Roberts SM. Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substance Toxicity and Human Health Review: Current State of Knowledge and Strategies for Informing Future Research. Environ Toxicol Chem. 2021 Mar

69.risks: Kidney cancer, testicular cancer, ulcerative colitis, thyroid disease, hypercholesterolemia, and pregnancy-induced hypertension

12.name: Total Trihalomethanes
12.description: Total trihalomethanes (TTHMs) are a group of chemical compounds formed as byproducts when chlorine or other disinfectants react with organic matter in water during the water purification process. They are considered environmental contaminants with potential health risks.

sources.label: PMC6193180 â Trihalomethanes in Drinking Water and Human Health
PubMed â Health risks from exposure to trihalomethanes in drinking water

12.risks: Carcinogenicity, increased risk of bladder cancer, potential liver and kidney toxicity, possible reproductive effects, environmental contaminant

30.name: Chloroform
30.description: A by product of the chlorination process used in water treatment
30.risks: Classified as a probable human carcinogen, with potential risks including increased cancer risk and negative effects on the liver, kidneys, and central nervous system upon prolonged exposure.
30.benefits: Used in water supplies to eliminate harmful microorganisms.

542.name: Strontium
542.description: Strontium is a naturally occurring mineral in trace amounts in the human body and is chemically similar to calcium. While some strontium compounds can influence bone metabolism, strontium is not considered an essential nutrient, and its supplementation can impact calcium absorption and bone health.

sources.label: PubMed â Strontium ranelate: a novel bone therapeutic agent
PubMed â Strontium in bone metabolism: Pharmacology and toxicology

542.risks: Possible interference with calcium metabolism, bone mineralization issues at high doses, increased risk of cardiovascular events with certain compounds, not established as essential, potential for toxicity
542.benefits: May improve bone mineral density in certain populations

410.name: Lithium
410.description: Lithium is an alkali metal used as a pharmaceutical agent, primarily in the form of lithium carbonate or lithium citrate, for the treatment of mood disorders such as bipolar disorder. It is not a dietary or food ingredient and has pharmacological effects on the nervous system.

sources.label: PMC6678377 â Lithium Use in Psychiatry
PubMed â Lithium Toxicity

410.risks: Toxicity at high doses, kidney damage, thyroid dysfunction, gastrointestinal distress, neurotoxicity, teratogenicity
410.benefits: Mood stabilization in bipolar disorder, reduction of suicide risk in psychiatric patients

16.name: Radium 226/228
16.description: A naturally occurring radioactive metal that can be found in some groundwater sources.

sources.label: Public Health Statement for Radium
Canu IG, Laurent O, Pires N, Laurier D, Dublineau I. Health effects of naturally radioactive water ingestion: the need for enhanced studies. Environ Health Perspect. 2011 Dec;119
Cancer in drinking water - Illinois department of public health

16.risks: Increased cancer risk, especially bone cancer, due to its radioactivity when ingested.

47.name: Aluminum
47.description: Often comes from the dissolution of aluminum-containing minerals or from human activities like mining and industrial processes. While aluminum is the most abundant metal in the earth's crust, it is not considered essential for human health.

sources.label: Aluminium in Drinking-water
Coagulation and Flocculation in Water and Wastewater Treatment
Meagan L. Weisner, Michael S. Harris, Diana Mitsova, Weibo Liu, Drinking water disparities and aluminum concentrations: 2023

47.risks: Neurological impacts such as cognitive impairment and an increased risk of developing conditions like Alzheimer's disease

650.name: Nitrate-N
650.description: Nitrate-N is a form of nitrogen that occurs naturally in soil and water, but can also be introduced through agricultural runoff and sewage contamination.
650.risks: High levels of nitrate in drinking water can cause methemoglobinemia (blue baby syndrome) in infants and may be associated with increased cancer risk in adults.
650.benefits: Nitrate is an essential nutrient for plant growth and is used in fertilizers to improve crop yields.

29.name: Bromodichloromethane
29.description: Bromodichloromethane is a chemical compound classified as a trihalomethane, commonly formed as a byproduct when chlorine disinfectants react with organic matter in water. It is not added intentionally to foods but can be present in drinking water and, subsequently, processed foods prepared with chlorinated water.

sources.label: Book: Bromodichloromethane - NCBI Bookshelf (Toxicological Profile)
PubMed â Cancer risk and trihalomethanes in drinking water

29.risks: Potential carcinogen, liver toxicity, kidney toxicity, reproductive toxicity, suspected endocrine disruptor

31.name: Dibromochloromethane
31.description: Dibromochloromethane is a halogenated organic compound that can form as a byproduct during water disinfection processes such as chlorination. It is not intentionally added to foods but can be present as a contaminant in drinking water, occasionally making its way into processed foods or beverages.

sources.label: PMC1247434 â Health effects of disinfection by-products
PubMed â Evidence for carcinogenicity of trihalomethanes

31.risks: Potential carcinogen, suspected reproductive toxin, liver toxicity, possible kidney effects

157.name: Borate
157.description: Borate refers to salts or esters of boric acid, often used as preservatives, buffering agents, or antiseptics in industrial and some food applications. Ingested borates can be absorbed and affect metabolic processes in the human body.

sources.label: PMC1570778 â Boron Exposure and Toxicity in Humans
PubMed â Safety evaluation of borates

157.risks: Toxicity at low levels, reproductive toxicity, developmental toxicity, gastrointestinal irritation, renal impairment

24.name: Uranium
24.description: A naturally occurring radioactive element that can leach into groundwater from surrounding rock and soil.

sources.label: Emerging health risks and underlying toxicological mechanisms of uranium contamination
Uranium in drinking water, naturally
BjÃ¸rklund G, Semenova Y, Pivina L, Dadar M, Rahman MM, Aaseth J, Chirumbolo S. Uranium in drinking water: a public health threat.

24.risks: Can cause kidney damage, increase cancer risk, and lead to other health issues like impacts on bone health and reproductive systems.

14.name: Gross Alpha
14.description: Measures the total alpha radiation emitted by all alpha-emitting radionuclides in a water sample, such as uranium and thorium, to assess overall alpha radiation levels.

sources.label: Okunola OJ, Oladipo MOA, Aker T, Popoola OB. Risk assessment of drinkable water sources using gross alpha and beta radioactivity levels and heavy metals. Heliyon. 2020 Aug 29s
Gross Alpha Radiation in Drinking Water - Vermont Department of Health

Yan Shi, Wa Gao, Tuya Siqin, Zhigang Li, Jianwei Zhang, Rongshu Guan, Jinfeng Li, Peilin Sun, Hongtao Zhao, The gross Î± and Î² radioactivity levels of drinking water source in one oil industrial city in northeast China, 2021

14.risks: Internal tissue damage and increased cancer risk due to their ionizing nature when ingested or inhaled.

568.name: Coconut water concentrate
568.description: Coconut water concentrate is made by removing water from coconut water, often by evaporation, to reduce its volume for shipping and storage; it is typically reconstituted with water before use. It provides some electrolytes like potassium but may lose some phytonutrients and flavor components during processing.

sources.label: PMC2769624 â Coconut water as a rehydration beverage
ScienceDirect â Nutritional composition of coconut water and effects of processing

568.risks: Potential loss of nutrients during processing, possible heavy metal contamination, may contain added sugars (if not pure), less phytonutrient content compared to fresh coconut water
568.benefits: Hydration, provides potassium, supplies some electrolytes

518.name: Citric acid
518.description: Citric acid is an organic acid naturally found in citrus fruits, widely used as a food preservative, flavor enhancer, and acidulant in processed foods and beverages. Industrially produced citric acid is typically obtained via fermentation using Aspergillus niger mold.

sources.label: PubMed â Citric acid in foods and its safety profile
PMC6492200 â Industrial citric acid production and health implications

518.risks: Potential for allergic reactions in sensitive individuals, possible digestive irritation at high intakes, industrial production source allergens
518.benefits: Enhances flavor, preserves shelf life, acts as antioxidant

560.name: Potassium citrate
560.description: Potassium citrate is the potassium salt of citric acid, used in food as a buffering agent, preservative, and to improve mineral balance; in the body, it helps regulate acid-base balance and is sometimes prescribed to prevent kidney stones.

sources.label: PMC7991285 â Potassium intake and health
PubMed â Potassium citrate in nephrolithiasis management

560.risks: Hyperkalemia with excessive intake, gastrointestinal upset in sensitive individuals, may interact with certain medications (e.g. ACE inhibitors, potassium-sparing diuretics)
560.benefits: Supports electrolyte balance, may reduce risk of kidney stones, alkalinizes urine

569.name: Acacia gum
569.description: Acacia gum, also known as gum arabic, is a natural polysaccharide harvested from acacia tree sap, commonly used as a stabilizer, thickener, and source of dietary fiber in food products. In the body, it acts primarily as a prebiotic fiber, supporting gut health and promoting beneficial microbial activity.

sources.label: PMC6678865 â Dietary fibers including gum arabic and their health effects
ScienceDirect â Nutritional and health aspects of gum arabic

569.risks: Mild gastrointestinal discomfort at high doses, rare allergic reactions
569.benefits: Source of soluble fiber, prebiotic effects, may improve glycemic control, may aid in cholesterol management

563.name: Stevia leaf extract
563.description: Stevia leaf extract is a high-intensity, zero-calorie sweetener derived from the Stevia rebaudiana plant, commonly used in foods and beverages as a sugar substitute due to its potent sweetness and negligible caloric value.

sources.label: PMC4890837 â Safety Assessment of Steviol Glycosides
PubMed â Stevia and gut microbiota

563.risks: Potential gut microbiota disruption, possible digestive discomfort, ultra-processed, may affect glycemic response in some individuals
563.benefits: Does not raise blood glucose levels, zero calories, suitable for individuals with diabetes

570.name: Sea salt
570.description: Sea salt is a mineral salt produced by evaporating seawater. It provides sodium and traces of other minerals and is commonly used as a seasoning and preservative in food products.

sources.label: PMC4997432 â Effects of different types of salt
PubMed â Heavy metals and microplastics in sea salt

570.risks: Excess sodium intake, potential contaminant exposure (microplastics, heavy metals)
570.benefits: Source of sodium, contains trace minerals

571.name: Tea extract
571.description: Tea extract is a concentrated form of bioactive compounds derived from tea leaves (Camellia sinensis), typically standardized for polyphenols such as catechins. It is used in foods and supplements for its antioxidant and purported health-promoting properties.

sources.label: PMC6520897 â Tea polyphenols in promotion of human health
PubMed â Green tea extract: A potential cause of acute liver failure

571.risks: Possible liver toxicity in high doses, gastrointestinal discomfort, caffeine-related side effects
571.benefits: Antioxidant activity, potential cardiovascular benefits, mild metabolic enhancement

572.name: Green coffee bean extract
572.description: Green coffee bean extract is derived from unroasted coffee beans and is rich in chlorogenic acids, compounds thought to have antioxidant properties and potential effects on blood sugar metabolism.

sources.label: PubMed â Efficacy and safety of green coffee bean extract in overweight individuals
PMC3941827 â Green coffee for weight loss: systematic review

572.risks: Possible gastrointestinal discomfort, unknown long-term safety, potential for increased heart rate or blood pressure in sensitive individuals, interaction with certain medications
572.benefits: Contains antioxidants, may help modestly reduce blood pressure, may have minor effects on glucose metabolism

543.name: Malic Acid
543.description: Malic acid is an organic acid naturally found in many fruits, especially apples, and is widely used as a food additive for its sour taste and preservative properties.

sources.label: PubMed â Malic acid as a food additive and its biological roles
ScienceDirect â Malic acid in food and metabolism

543.risks: Possible gastrointestinal irritation in sensitive individuals, rare allergic reactions
543.benefits: May enhance mineral absorption, involved in cellular energy production

1265.name: NeuroFactor Coffee Fruit Extract (100 mg)
1265.description: NeuroFactor is a standardized extract derived from the whole coffee fruit (Coffea arabica), containing various polyphenols and bioactive compounds. It is marketed for its ability to increase brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), a protein involved in neuroplasticity and cognitive function.

sources.label: PMC5258575 â Acute supplementation with coffee fruit extract increases plasma BDNF in healthy subjects
PubMed â NeuroFactor coffee extract and plasma BDNF

1265.risks: Possible mild gastrointestinal discomfort, insufficient long-term safety data, potential caffeine sensitivity
1265.benefits: May support increased BDNF, potential cognitive function support, source of polyphenols

917.name: Organic Monk Fruit Extract
917.description: Monk fruit extract is a natural calorie-free sweetener derived from the fruit of Siraitia grosvenorii. The extract contains mogrosides, which are responsible for its sweet taste and are recognized by the FDA as Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS). Organic versions are produced without synthetic pesticides or fertilizers.

sources.label: PMC6144086 â Non-nutritive sweeteners: Safety, risks, and public health perspectives
FDA GRAS Notice No. 718 â Monk Fruit Extract

917.risks: Possible mild gastrointestinal upset in sensitive individuals, ultra-processed, limited long-term studies
917.benefits: Calorie-free sugar alternative, does not raise blood glucose, low glycemic index

738.name: Zinc sulfate
738.description: Zinc sulfate is an inorganic compound used as a dietary zinc supplement and for fortifying foods. Zinc is an essential trace mineral involved in immune function, enzyme activity, and cellular metabolism.

sources.label: PubMed â Zinc in human health: effect of zinc on immune cells
NIH â Zinc Fact Sheet for Health Professionals

738.risks: Gastrointestinal irritation, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, metallic taste, risk of zinc toxicity with excessive intake
738.benefits: Supports immune function, essential for enzyme activity, aids in wound healing, contributes to normal growth and development

3294.name: DL-Alpha Tocopheryl Acetate (Vitamin E)
3294.description: DL-Alpha Tocopheryl Acetate is a synthetic form of vitamin E commonly used as a dietary supplement or food additive to provide antioxidant benefits and prevent rancidity in products. It is less bioavailable than the natural form (d-alpha tocopherol).

sources.label: PMC3997530 â Bioavailability and effectiveness of vitamin E forms
PubMed â Efficacy and safety of vitamin E supplements

3294.risks: Lower bioavailability compared to natural form, potential adverse effects at high doses, synthetic processing
3294.benefits: Antioxidant activity, supports immune function, may prevent vitamin E deficiency

567.name: Erythritol
567.description: Erythritol is a sugar alcohol used as a low-calorie sweetener in a variety of foods and beverages. It is mostly absorbed in the small intestine and largely excreted unchanged in urine, resulting in minimal impact on blood glucose and little caloric contribution.

sources.label: PMC6679136 â Erythritol: An In-Depth Review of Its Potential Health Effects
PMC10077809 â The artificial sweetener erythritol and cardiovascular event risk

567.risks: Digestive discomfort at high doses, potential gut microbiome disruption, possible association with increased cardiovascular event risk
567.benefits: Low glycemic impact, reduced calorie intake, does not promote tooth decay

548.name: Cherry Juice Concentrate
548.description: Cherry juice concentrate is a syrup-like form of cherry juice produced by removing much of the natural water content. It is used as a sweetener, flavor enhancer, and coloring agent, and retains certain phytonutrients found in cherries, such as anthocyanins, though some beneficial compounds may be lost during processing.

sources.label: PubMed â Effects of tart cherry juice concentrate on exercise-induced muscle damage
PMC â Cherries and Health: A Review of the Current Evidence

548.risks: High sugar content, potential to raise blood glucose, possible loss of phytonutrients compared to whole cherries
548.benefits: Contains antioxidants, source of anthocyanins, may reduce exercise-induced muscle soreness, potential anti-inflammatory effects

664.name: Organic blackberry juice concentrate
664.description: Organic blackberry juice concentrate is produced by removing water from juice pressed from organically grown blackberries, resulting in a dense source of natural sugars, anthocyanins, vitamins, and antioxidants often used as a flavoring or sweetener in processed foods and beverages.

sources.label: PubMed â Phenolics and antioxidant capacity of blackberries
PubMed â Health-promoting compounds in berries

664.risks: High natural sugar content, possible loss of heat-sensitive nutrients during processing
664.benefits: Source of anthocyanins, antioxidants, micronutrients, anti-inflammatory potential

686.name: Vegetable juice concentrate (color)
686.description: Vegetable juice concentrate for color is typically made by processing and concentrating the juice of vegetables, such as beets or carrots, to create a coloring agent for foods. It is used to enhance or standardize the appearance of processed foods without providing significant nutritional benefit.

sources.label: PMC7286891 â Applications of Fruit and Vegetable Juices as Natural Colorants
PubMed â Application of fruit and vegetable juices as colorants

686.risks: Ultra-processed, potential loss of nutrients during processing, rare allergic reactions

3160.name: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C)
3160.description: Ascorbic acid is the chemically isolated form of vitamin C, commonly used as a dietary supplement and as a preservative in foods due to its antioxidant properties. It helps with collagen synthesis, immune function, and iron absorption.

sources.label: PubMed â Vitamin C in health and disease
NIH â Vitamin C Fact Sheet for Health Professionals

3160.risks: Gastrointestinal upset at high doses, possible kidney stone risk in predisposed individuals
3160.benefits: Antioxidant activity, supports immune function, enhances iron absorption, essential for collagen synthesis

3243.name: Fruit Juice Concentrates (for Color)
3243.description: Fruit juice concentrate used for color is produced by removing water from fruit juice, resulting in a high-sugar, low-nutrient syrup used primarily as a natural coloring agent in processed foods.

sources.label: PMC4490972 â Juice concentrates in processed foods: composition and health implications
PubMed â Food colorants from fruit concentrates: safety and nutritional evaluation

3243.risks: Ultra-processed ingredient, minimal nutritional value, possible residual contaminants, may contain added sugars, may contribute to misleading 'natural' labeling

3246.name: Monk Fruit Extract
3246.description: Monk fruit extract is a natural, calorie-free sweetener derived from the fruit of Siraitia grosvenorii. The sweet compoundsâmogrosidesâare responsible for its intense sweetness. The extract is FDA GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe) for use as a sweetener in foods and beverages.

sources.label: NCBI â Updates on safety and health benefits of Monk Fruit
NCBI â Monk Fruit: Potential benefits and safety evaluation
FDA â High-Intensity Sweeteners Permitted for Use

3246.risks: Potential digestive discomfort in large amounts, lack of long-term safety data
3246.benefits: No glycemic impact, zero calories, suitable for diabetics

65.name: Copper
65.description: Copper is an essential trace mineral involved in numerous enzymatic reactions, playing critical roles in energy production, antioxidant defense, and connective tissue formation.

sources.label: NCBI Bookshelf â Copper
PubMed â Copper in human health

65.risks: Toxicity at high doses, gastrointestinal distress, liver damage, potential neurotoxicity
65.benefits: Supports energy metabolism, essential for iron metabolism, antioxidant defense, connective tissue formation, neurological function

125.name: Soluble Corn Fiber
125.description: Soluble corn fiber is a synthetic or semi-synthetic dietary fiber made from corn starch, often used as a low-calorie bulking agent and fiber additive in processed foods to improve texture and fiber content.

sources.label: PMC6413106 â Health effects and mechanisms of dietary fiber
PubMed â Gastrointestinal tolerance of soluble corn fiber

125.risks: Digestive discomfort, gas, bloating, poorly characterized effects on gut microbiota, highly processed, potential for misleading fiber claims
125.benefits: Mild increase in stool bulk, slight improvement in laxation

62.name: Lead
62.description: A toxic metal that can leach into drinking water from old lead pipes and plumbing fixtures. Recommended health limits can vary for certain populations as follows: children 2.2 mcg per day, females of childbearing age  8.8 mcg.

sources.label: EWG Lead
California Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment, Public Health Goal for Lead in Drinking Water. 2009.

62.risks: Developmental issues, cognitive impairments, and various other serious health problems.

39.name: Nitrite
39.description: Often present as a pollutant, that can originate from agricultural runoff, industrial waste, or natural processes

sources.label: Health Effects from Exposure to Nitrates and Nitrites

Roberto Picetti, Megan Deeney, Silvia Pastorino, Mark R. Miller, Anoop Shah, David A. Leon, Alan D. Dangour, Rosemary Green, Nitrate and nitrite contamination in drinking water and cancer risk: A systematic review with meta-analysis 2022
Health Concerns Related to Nitrate and Nitrite in Private Well Water

39.risks: Harmful, especially to infants and pregnant women, as it interferes with blood's ability to carry oxygen, potentially leading to a condition known as methemoglobinemia or "blue baby syndrome".

59.name: Zinc
59.description: Zinc is an essential trace mineral required for immune function, enzyme activity, protein synthesis, wound healing, and DNA synthesis. It is found naturally in animal foods, legumes, and nuts, and is commonly added to supplements and fortified foods.

sources.label: PMC3724376 â Physiological and Health-Related Roles of Zinc
NIH Fact Sheet: Zinc

59.risks: High-dose supplementation can cause nausea, vomiting, impaired copper absorption, immune dysfunction with long-term excess
59.benefits: Supports immune function, required for enzyme activity, aids in wound healing, necessary for DNA synthesis, supports normal growth and development

162.name: Radium 228
162.description: Radium-228 is a radioactive isotope of radium that is a weak beta emitter. It is a product of thorium-232 decay and has a half-life of 6.7 years.

sources.label: EWG Radium 226 and 228

162.risks: Can cause significant damage to internal tissues and increases the risk of bone cancer, as radium can replace calcium in bones.
162.benefits: Historically used in medical therapies and luminescent products

149.name: Stevia Sweetener
149.description: Stevia sweetener is a high-intensity, zero-calorie sugar substitute derived from the leaves of the Stevia rebaudiana plant. It is used to provide sweetness in foods and drinks without adding calories or raising blood glucose levels.

sources.label: PMC4890837 â Steviol glycosides: Health perspectives and regulatory status
PubMed â Effects of stevia on health markers

149.risks: Digestive upset (at high intake), potential microbiome impact, ultra-processed, possible allergenicity
149.benefits: Non-caloric sweetener, does not raise blood glucose or insulin levels

32.name: Radon
32.description: A naturally occurring radioactive gas that can dissolve and accumulate in groundwater sources

sources.label: Basic Information about Radon in Drinking Water EPA
Risk Assessment of Radon in Drinking Water.
Radon - WHO

32.risks: Prolonged ingestion of water with high radon levels may also contribute to internal organ cancers, particularly stomach cancer.

83.name: Selenium
83.description: Selenium is an essential trace mineral important for antioxidant defense, thyroid function, and immune system support. It is a component of selenoproteins, which help protect cells from oxidative damage and regulate metabolic processes.

sources.label: NIH Office of Dietary Supplements â Selenium
PubMed â Selenium in human health and disease

83.risks: Toxicity at high doses, selenosis, gastrointestinal disturbance, hair/nail brittleness or loss, neurological abnormalities
83.benefits: Supports antioxidant defense, thyroid hormone metabolism, immune system function, may reduce risk of certain cancers

112.name: Vanadium
112.description: Vanadium is the 21st most abundant element in the Earthâs crust and the 2nd-to-most abundant transition metal in sea water.

sources.label: Vanadium. Its Role for Humans. National Library of Medicine
Chapter 1: Introduction: Vanadium, Its Compounds and Applications. Vanadium Catalysis. Royal Society of Chemistry
Sources of Vanadium

112.risks: The main source for potentially toxic effects caused by vanadium is exposure to high loads of vanadium oxides in the breathing air of vanadium processing industrial enterprises. Vanadium can enter the body via the lungs or, more commonly, the stomach. Most of the dietary vanadium is excreted.
112.benefits: It is an important component of specific steel alloys since it promotes lightness and provides additional tensile strength of these materials and prevents corrosion. Vanadium oxides can be applied in manufacturing of ceramics, production of coatings for electrochemical tools of energy storage equipment, microelectronic devices and specific glasses used for the production of smart windows.

153.name: Strontium-90
153.description: Strontium-90 is a radioactive isotope produced during nuclear fission, not a food ingredient, and is considered an environmental contaminant. When ingested, it behaves similarly to calcium, accumulating in bones and bone marrow, where it emits beta radiation and poses serious health risks.

sources.label: PubMed â Health effects of exposure to strontium-90
NCBI Bookshelf â Toxicological profile for strontium (Chapter: Strontium-90)

153.risks: Radiation exposure, bone cancer, leukemia, accumulates in bone tissue, disrupts bone marrow function, toxic contamination

408.name: Cobalt
408.description: Refined or polished cobalt is a silvery white metal and have a faint bluish tinge.  Its physical properties resemble iron and nickel. Cobalt is a ferromagnetic.

sources.label: Periodic Table Cobalt

408.risks: Exposure to high level of cobalt, they can suffer from lungs infections such as asthma and pneumonia.
408.benefits: Cobalt has been used as a coloring agent since Bronze Age. Primarily used in making magnets.

531.name: Phosphorus
531.description: Phosphorus is an essential mineral involved in bone health, energy metabolism, and cellular signaling. It occurs naturally in many foods and is sometimes added to processed foods as a preservative or texturizer.

sources.label: PMC1120864 â Dietary phosphorus and health
PubMed â Phosphorus and bone health

531.risks: Hyperphosphatemia with excess intake, risk of kidney damage in chronic kidney disease, can contribute to cardiovascular disease if consumed in excess (especially from phosphate additives)
531.benefits: Supports bone formation, energy metabolism, cellular function, DNA and RNA synthesis

163.name: Radium 226
163.description: Radium-226 is a radioactive isotope of radium that decays into radon-222. It's found in uranium ores and soils, and is a major source of radioactivity in uranium mine tailings.Â

sources.label: EWG Radium 226 & 228

163.risks: Harmful when ingested or inhaled, leading to internal tissue damage and increased cancer risks, particularly if accumulated in the body.

352.name: Phenols
352.description: It is a colorless-to-white solid when pure. Phenol solution, [aqueous] is a white crystalline mass dissolved in an aqueous solution. Solution may be colorless to slightly pink in color with a distinctive phenol odor; sharp burning taste.

sources.label: Compound Summary Phenols. National Library of Medicine.

352.risks: Consumption of water contaminated with phenol resulted in diarrhea, mouth sores, burning of the mouth, and dark urine. Phenol is highly caustic to tissues. Skin exposure results in pain, then numbness, blanching, severe burns, and eschar formation. Ingestion leads to burning of throat and severe gastrointestinal inflammation.
352.benefits: The primary use of phenol is in the production of phenolic resins, which are used in the plywood, construction, automotive, and appliance industries. Other uses of phenol include as a slimicide, as a disinfectant, and in medicinal products such as ear and nose drops, throat lozenges, and mouthwashes.

913.name: Aspartame
913.description: Aspartame is an artificial, low-calorie sweetener approximately 200 times sweeter than sugar, commonly used in diet sodas, sugar-free foods, and low-calorie products. It breaks down into phenylalanine, aspartic acid, and methanol in the body.

sources.label: PMC7871826 â Aspartame: A review of neurological and behavioral health effects
PubMed â Artificial sweeteners and cancer risk: An evidence review

913.risks: Phenylalanine buildup in phenylketonuria (PKU), potential for headaches, possible alteration of gut microbiota, controversial links to cancer and neurological effects in high doses, ultra-processed, not suitable for all populations
913.benefits: Reduced calorie intake, does not raise blood glucose

545.name: Potassium Benzoate
545.description: Potassium benzoate is a synthetic preservative commonly used in soft drinks, juices, and processed foods to inhibit the growth of mold, yeast, and bacteria.

sources.label: PMC4924387 â A review of benzoate toxicity and metabolism
PubMed â Adverse reactions to food additives

545.risks: Potential for benzene formation in presence of vitamin C, possible mild allergenicity, may disrupt gut microbiota with high intake, ultra-processed additive

151.name: Acesulfame Potassium
151.description: Acesulfame potassium, also known as Ace-K, is a calorie-free artificial sweetener used to replace sugar in food and beverages. It is approximately 200 times sweeter than sucrose and is chemically synthesized.

sources.label: PubMed â Artificial sweeteners and gut microbiome
PMC â Health implications of acesulfame potassium

151.risks: Potential gut microbiome disruption, possible metabolic effects, limited long-term safety data, may promote sweetness preference

66.name: Spring water
66.description: Spring water is water sourced from a natural underground aquifer that flows to the surface, often marketed for its mineral content and purity, but its quality varies depending on the source and potential environmental contaminants.

sources.label: PMC7778073 â Drinking water quality and public health
PubMed â Chemical composition and safety of bottled spring water

66.risks: Possible contamination with microorganisms, heavy metals, agricultural runoff, variable mineral content
66.benefits: Hydration, source of minerals (variable depending on source)

327.name: Di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate
327.description: Di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) is a synthetic compound commonly used as a plasticizer in food packaging materials. It can migrate into foods, particularly fatty foods, and is known for its endocrine-disrupting properties and multiple toxicological risks.

sources.label: PMC7403879 â Health effects of phthalate exposure
PubMed â Toxicological drivers of phthalate exposure

327.risks: Endocrine disruption, reproductive toxicity, developmental toxicity, increased risk of cancer, liver and kidney damage, accumulation in body tissues

61.name: Chlorine
61.description: Primarily used as a disinfectant. It effectively eliminates harmful pathogens, including bacteria and viruses.

sources.label: National Toxicology Program. NTP Toxicology and Carcinogenesis Studies of Chlorinated Water
Chlorination of Phenols Revisited: Unexpected Formation of Î±,Î²-Unsaturated C4-Dicarbonyl Ring Cleavage Products | Environmental Science & Technology

61.risks: Excessive chlorine levels can lead to unpleasant tastes and odors in water, and prolonged exposure to high chlorine concentrations may cause skin and eye irritation.

1012.name: Heterotrophic Plate Count
1012.description: A count of all carbon-consuming bacteria in water, the vast majority of which are harmless
1012.risks: Potential endocrine disruptor; long-term exposure is linked to hormonal disruption, reproductive toxicity, and developmental effects

34.name: Chloramine
34.description: Chloramine is a disinfectant formed by combining chlorine with ammonia, commonly used in municipal water treatment to control microbes. It is more stable than chlorine and persists longer in water distribution systems.

sources.label: PMC2897243 â Human health risk assessment of chloramine use in water disinfection
PubMed â Chloramines in water disinfection and health effects

34.risks: Can cause skin and eye irritation, unpleasant taste and odor, may form potentially harmful disinfection byproducts, risk of kidney or blood problems in dialysis patients, can impact sensitive aquarium and reptile species
34.benefits: Reduces microbial contamination in water, more stable disinfectant residual than chlorine

108.name: Protein Blend
108.description: A protein blend is a mixture of two or more protein sources, typically processed and combined to enhance texture, flavor, or amino acid profile in packaged foods. The exact composition is often undisclosed, making it difficult to determine source quality or processing methods.

sources.label: PMC9102077 â Evaluation of Protein Blends in Processed Foods
PubMed â Allergenic Risks and Processing of Composite Proteins

108.risks: Lack of transparency, potential allergen exposure, ultra-processed, may contain additives or contaminants

84.name: Silver
84.description: Silver is a metallic element sometimes used in medical devices, as a food additive (E174), or as colloidal silver supplements, although it has no essential role in human nutrition.

sources.label: PubMed â Toxicity of Silver
PMC2365910 â Silver as an Antimicrobial Agent

84.risks: Argyria (irreversible skin discoloration), potential kidney and liver toxicity, gastrointestinal irritation, microbiome disruption, accumulation in organs, not recognized as safe for supplements

105.name: Added Sugar
105.description: Added sugar refers to sugars and syrups incorporated into foods during processing or preparation, enhancing sweetness but providing no essential nutrients beyond calories.

sources.label: PMC4997437 â Health effects of dietary risks, including added sugar
PubMed â Added sugars and health outcomes

105.risks: Elevated risk of obesity, increased risk of type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, dental caries, cardiovascular disease, increased triglycerides, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease

107.name: Bisphenols
107.description: Bisphenols (e.g., BPA, BPS, BPF) are chemicals used to make plastics and resins durable and heat-resistant, often found in food containers and beverage bottles. They are known to leach into contents, especially when exposed to heat, posing potential health risks.
107.risks: Endocrine disruption, developmental and reproductive health effects, linked to chronic illnesses like diabetes and heart disease.

255.name: Phthalates
255.description: Group of synthetic chemical plasticizers used to increase flexibility in plastics, coatings, and packaging, and can migrate into food and beverages from plastic containers and processing materials.

sources.label: Compound Summary 2,4,5-Trichlorobiphenyl. National Library of Medicine

255.risks: Hormone disfunction, reproductive toxicity, developmental issues, metabolic disorders, endocrine disruption, lower sperm quality, reduced testosterone, possible carcinogen
255.benefits: CBs were used as coolants and lubricants in transformers, capacitors, and other electrical devices (such as fluorescent lights and refridgerators) produced before 1977. PCBs may contaminate the air and water near hazardous waste sites.

104.name: Molybdenum
104.description: Molybdenum is an essential trace mineral that acts as a cofactor for critical enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism, detoxification of sulfites, and breakdown of purines in the body.

sources.label: NIH: Molybdenum Fact Sheet for Health Professionals
PubMed â Molybdenum, an essential trace element

104.risks: Toxicity at high intake, may cause gout-like symptoms, copper deficiency if consumed excessively
104.benefits: Essential cofactor for enzymes, supports sulfur amino acid metabolism, assists in detoxification of sulfites

81.name: Beryllium
81.description: A steel-gray metal that is both strong and brittle, widely used in aerospace components, nuclear reactors, and electronic devices

sources.label: Cooper RG, Harrison AP. The uses and adverse effects of beryllium on health. Indian J Occup Environ Med. 2009 Aug
Beryllium - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

81.risks: Can lead to Berylliosis, a lung disease, and increased risk of lung cancer
81.benefits: No known beneficial biological function in the human body

110.name: Chlorodibromoacetic acid
110.description: Chlorodibromoacetic acid is synonymous with Dibromochloroacetic acid. It is classified as one of  haloacetic acids identified in chlorinated drinking water,  which is listed as reasonably anticipated to be a human carcinogen.

sources.label: Haloacetic Acids Found as Water Disinfection Byproducts (Selected). National Library of Medicine
Compound Summary. Chlorodibromoacetic Acid. National Institute of Medicine

657.name: 12-Stage Ultra-Purified Structured Water
657.description: Ultra-purified water that has undergone multiple filtration and purification steps, sometimes marketed as 'structured' for purported health benefits, though the 'structured' concept lacks credible scientific basis. Purified water may still contain trace contaminants depending on the source and process.

sources.label: PMC6277462 â Drinking water purification and public health: Benefits and risks
PubMed â Purified water: Health implications and recommended standards

657.risks: Potential residual contaminants, lacks essential minerals, misleading marketing claims, no physiological benefit over standard purified water

6.name: Magnesium Sulfate
6.description: Magnesium sulfate is an inorganic salt commonly used as a source of magnesium in food, supplements, and pharmaceuticals, as well as a firming agent. In the body, magnesium is essential for numerous biochemical reactions, including nerve function, muscle contraction, and bone health.

sources.label: PMC5452227 â Role of magnesium in health and disease
PubMed â Magnesium sulfate as a therapeutic agent

6.risks: Gastrointestinal upset at high doses, diarrhea, possible electrolyte imbalance with excessive intake
6.benefits: Supports magnesium levels, may relieve constipation, essential for nerve and muscle function, supports bone health

601.name: Organic guava natural flavor
601.description: A processed flavoring derived from guava, labeled organic, but formulated using chemical extraction methods. Intended to mimic guavaâs aroma or taste without providing whole fruit nutrition.

sources.label: PMC8026810 â Health implications of flavor additives
PubMed â Risk factors in food flavoring components

601.risks: Lack of transparency, ultra-processed, may contain undisclosed solvents or carriers, no nutritional value

1161.name: Salt (Sodium Chloride)
1161.description: Salt, or sodium chloride, is a crystalline mineral primarily used as a seasoning and preservative in food. Sodium is essential for fluid balance, nerve transmission, and muscle function, but excessive intake can affect cardiovascular health.

sources.label: PMC7283135 â Health effects of sodium consumption
PubMed â Dietary salt intake and human health

1161.risks: Hypertension, increased cardiovascular disease risk, kidney strain, may exacerbate osteoporosis
1161.benefits: Essential electrolyte, maintains fluid balance, supports nerve and muscle function

634.name: Magnesium Citrate
634.description: Magnesium citrate is a highly bioavailable form of magnesium, commonly used as a dietary supplement to support normal muscle and nerve function, bone health, and as a laxative due to its ability to attract water into the intestines.

sources.label: PMC5452227 â Magnesium in Disease Prevention and Overall Health
PubMed â Magnesium and Health Outcomes

634.risks: Gastrointestinal upset, diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance at high doses, potential interactions with certain medications
634.benefits: Improved magnesium status, supports muscle and nerve function, may relieve constipation, supports bone health, may help prevent migraine

6860.name: Silicon
6860.description: Silicon, as an ingredient in food products, typically refers to silicon dioxide or other silicon-based compounds used as anti-caking agents or supplements. In the human body, silicon plays a role in bone formation and connective tissue health but is not considered an essential nutrient.

sources.label: PMC2658806 â Silicon: A Review of Its Potential Role in Bone Health
PubMed â Silicon in Food and Drinking Water

6860.risks: High intake may cause kidney dysfunction in susceptible individuals, possible respiratory irritation (occupational exposure), limited nutritional value
6860.benefits: Potential support for bone health, connective tissue formation

651.name: Sulphate
651.description: Sulphate is a naturally occurring anion found in many minerals and commonly present in drinking water.

sources.label: How to Understand and Use the Nutrition Facts Label
Sulfate | Definition, Formula & Structure

651.risks: High concentrations of sulphate in drinking water can cause temporary gastrointestinal distress and have a laxative effect, particularly in infants and travelers not accustomed to the water.
651.benefits: Sulphate is an essential nutrient for many organisms and plays a role in various biological processes.

38.name: Chromium (hexavalent)
38.description: A toxic form of chromium, known chemically as Cr(VI). It often enters water sources through industrial processes like electroplating, leather tanning, and textile manufacturing

sources.label: Chromium in Water and Carcinogenic Human Health Risk
Health Effects of Arsenic and Chromium in Drinking Water
Chromium in Drinking Water: Sources, Metabolism, and Cancer Risks

38.risks: Increased risk of cancer, reproductive problems, and damage to the liver, kidney.

9693.name: Potassium
9693.description: Potassium is an essential dietary mineral and electrolyte necessary for fluid balance, nerve transmission, and muscle function. In food products, it is often used to enhance nutritional value and as a salt substitute.

sources.label: NIH â Potassium: Fact Sheet for Health Professionals
PubMed â Dietary potassium intake and risk of stroke

9693.risks: Hyperkalemia (excess potassium in blood) in individuals with kidney dysfunction, gastrointestinal discomfort at high doses
9693.benefits: Supports normal blood pressure, essential for cell function, aids nerve and muscle function, reduces risk of stroke

35.name: CO2
35.description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a naturally occurring, colorless, and odorless gas used in food and beverage processing for carbonation, preservation, and packaging. In the body, it is a normal metabolic byproduct expelled during respiration.

sources.label: PMC5227942 â Carbon dioxide in food processing and preservation
PubMed â Carbonation of beverages and impact on human health

35.risks: None at concentrations typically used in food and beverages

575.name: Agave nectar
575.description: Agave nectar is a sweetener derived from the agave plant, commonly used as an alternative to sugar or honey. It is primarily composed of fructose and has a high glycemic impact despite marketing claims.

sources.label: PMC4997435 â High fructose intake and health
PubMed â Fructose, insulin resistance, and metabolic disorders

575.risks: High fructose content, potential for liver stress, insulin resistance, increased triglycerides, possible metabolic syndrome
575.benefits: Low glycemic index compared to table sugar

36.name: Haloacetic acids (HAA9)
36.description: A group of chemicals that are formed when chlorine or other disinfectants used to treat drinking water react with naturally occurring organic and inorganic matter in water.

sources.label: Haloacetic Acids Found as Water Disinfection Byproducts
EWG Haloacetic Acids (HAA9)
Public Health Goal for Haloacetic Acids

36.risks: Increased risk of cancer and potential reproductive and developmental issues,

60.name: Chlorine Dioxide
60.description: Chlorine dioxide is a chemical compound commonly used as a disinfectant and bleaching agent in water treatment and food processing to reduce microbial contamination.

sources.label: PMC3774764 â Toxicological Profile for Chlorine Dioxide and Chlorite
PubMed â Assessment of risks associated with the use of chlorine dioxide

60.risks: Oxidative stress, gastrointestinal irritation, potential formation of harmful byproducts, toxicity with improper use
60.benefits: Reduces microbial contamination in water and food processing

683.name: Purified water
683.description: Purified water is water that has been filtered or processed to remove impurities and contaminants, but may still contain trace elements, disinfection byproducts, or residual contaminants depending on the purification method used.

sources.label: PubMed â Health risks from drinking demineralized and purified water
PMC4145278 â Drinking water contamination and purification

683.risks: May contain trace contaminants, disinfection byproducts, lacks minerals, possible microbiological risks

1112.name: Encapsulated citric acid
1112.description: Encapsulated citric acid is citric acid coated with a protective material (often hydrogenated oils, starches, or gums) to delay its release in food products, commonly used for controlled acidity and improved shelf life.

sources.label: PubMed â Applications and effects of organic acid encapsulation
ScienceDirect â Encapsulation techniques for organic acids in food

1112.risks: May use processed coating materials, contributes to acidity load, potential for digestive irritation with overconsumption, ultra-processed additive
1112.benefits: Extends shelf life in food products, controls acidification timing

546.name: Sucralose
546.description: Sucralose is an artificial, non-nutritive sweetener approximately 600 times sweeter than sucrose. Frequently used in processed foods and beverages, it is not metabolized by the body for energy and largely excreted unchanged. Recent studies raise concerns about its effects on the gut microbiota and potential for metabolic disruption.

sources.label: PMC9066738 â Sucralose: A Critical Review of Its Metabolism and Health Effects
PubMed â Effects of Sucralose on the Gut Microbiome

546.risks: Gut microbiome alteration, potential glucose homeostasis disruption, possible pro-inflammatory effects, environmental persistence

631.name: Potassium sorbate
631.description: Potassium sorbate is a synthetic preservative commonly added to foods and beverages to inhibit the growth of mold, yeast, and some bacteria, thereby extending shelf life.

sources.label: PubMed â Effects of potassium sorbate on cell viability and genotoxicity
PMC5762128 â Food additives and gut microbiota

631.risks: Possible allergenic reactions, potential genotoxicity at high doses, may disrupt gut microbiome, no nutritional value

398.name: Chlorodibromomethane
398.description: Chlorodibromomethane is a colorless to yellow, heavy, nonflammable compound that was formerly used as a flame retardant and chemical intermediate but is now only used as a laboratory reagent. It is also produced in small amounts by algae in the ocean and can be found in chlorinated drinking water as a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine, natural organic substances, and bromide during the water treatment process.
398.risks: Limited evidence of carcinogenicity in animals, genotoxic and mutagenic effects in various test systems, and toxic effects on the liver, kidney, immune system, and thyroid in high-dose animal studies

900.name: HFPO-DA (PFAS)
900.description: HFPO-DA, commonly known as GenX, is a next-generation per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance (PFAS) used as a surfactant in industrial and food-contact applications. It is persistent in the environment and can accumulate in living organisms, raising concerns over toxicity and long-term health effects.

sources.label: PMC7929737 â GenX and the replacement of PFOS/PFOA: Environmental health concerns
PubMed â Effects of HFPO-DA on liver and kidney function

900.risks: Bioaccumulation, potential carcinogenicity, liver toxicity, kidney toxicity, endocrine disruption, environmental persistence

671.name: Sugar
671.description: Sugar, typically in the form of sucrose, is a simple carbohydrate used widely as a sweetener in foods and beverages. It is rapidly absorbed and metabolized by the body, providing a quick source of energy.

sources.label: PMC5174155 â Sugar consumption and health: Is there a role for the foods industry?
PubMed â Added sugars and health: a review

671.risks: High intake associated with obesity, increased risk of type 2 diabetes, dental caries, metabolic syndrome, increased triglycerides, cardiovascular risk
671.benefits: Quick source of energy, necessary substrate for cellular metabolism in small quantities

1531.name: Aroma
1531.description: Aroma is a generic term for fragrance or odor compounds added to foods to enhance or modify their smell and sometimes taste. In labeling, it often refers to both natural and artificial flavoring substances, and its exact composition is rarely disclosed.

sources.label: PMC9159861 â Flavorings and Additives in Food: Health Risks and Regulatory Considerations
PubMed â Risk factors in food flavoring components

1531.risks: Lack of transparency, possible presence of artificial chemicals, ultra-processed, may cause allergic reactions, no nutritional value

3544.name: Natural Mineral Water
3544.description: Natural mineral water is bottled water sourced from an underground aquifer and is characterized by a stable mineral composition and the absence of chemical treatment. It may contain naturally occurring minerals beneficial to human health, such as calcium and magnesium.

sources.label: PubMed â Health benefits and risks of bottled water
PMC6429223 â Mineral water: Health effects and regulatory overview

3544.risks: May contain trace contaminants, geological variability in mineral content
3544.benefits: Provides hydration, source of minerals like calcium and magnesium

3545.name: Fructose-glucose syrup
3545.description: Fructose-glucose syrup, also known as high-fructose corn syrup, is a liquid sweetener produced by enzymatic conversion of cornstarch, resulting in a mixture of fructose and glucose. It is used in processed foods and beverages for its sweetness and preservative properties.

sources.label: PMC4997435 â Consumption of fructose, high fructose corn syrup, and their health effects
PubMed â Health effects of fructose consumption

3545.risks: Increased risk of obesity, metabolic syndrome, insulin resistance, fatty liver, elevated triglycerides, risk of type 2 diabetes, increased uric acid levels, cardiovascular disease risk

3546.name: Citric Acid
3546.description: Citric acid is a weak organic acid commonly found in citrus fruits and widely used as a flavoring, preservative, and acidulant in processed foods. Industrially, it is typically produced via fermentation using the mold Aspergillus niger.

sources.label: PMC6277462 â Citric Acid: A Versatile Ingredient
PubMed â Citric Acid Applications in Food Technology

3546.risks: Possible allergenic reactions in sensitive individuals, potential to cause gastrointestinal upset or mouth irritation in high amounts, industrial source may contain impurities
3546.benefits: Enhances flavor stability, supports food preservation, low toxicity at typical dietary levels

3547.name: Tea Infusion (0.1%)
3547.description: Tea infusion is a water-based extract made by steeping tea leaves (Camellia sinensis) in hot water, resulting in the transfer of polyphenols, caffeine, amino acids, and other phytochemicals into the liquid. At 0.1%, the concentration is very low compared to typical brewed tea.

sources.label: PMC6520897 â Health benefits of tea consumption
PubMed â Polyphenol content and antioxidant activity of tea infusions

3548.name: Peach juice (0.1%) from concentrate
3548.description: Peach juice from concentrate is made by extracting the water from peach juice to form a concentrate, which is then reconstituted with water before use; the low percentage indicates minimal peach-derived nutrients in the final product.

sources.label: PMC6150141 â Effect of juice processing on nutritional quality
ScienceDirect â Nutritional properties of peach juice and effects of processing

3548.risks: Ultra-processed, minimal phytonutrients, potential residual processing compounds

3549.name: Ascorbic Acid
3549.description: Ascorbic acid, commonly known as vitamin C, is an essential vitamin often added to foods as a preservative and antioxidant. It plays a key role in collagen synthesis, immune function, and the absorption of iron from plant sources.

sources.label: PMC5707683 â Vitamin C in health and disease
PubMed â Safety and efficacy of vitamin C

3549.risks: Gastrointestinal discomfort at high doses, possible kidney stone formation in predisposed individuals at very high intake
3549.benefits: Antioxidant properties, supports immune function, enhances iron absorption, essential for collagen synthesis

3550.name: Sucralose
3550.description: Sucralose is a synthetic, non-nutritive sweetener approximately 600 times sweeter than sucrose, widely used in processed foods and beverages as a calorie-free sugar substitute.

sources.label: PMC8613984 â Effects of sucralose on the gut microbiome
PubMed â Sucralose affects glycemic and hormonal responses
PMC6631139 â Genotoxicity and safety evaluations of sucralose

3550.risks: Gut microbiome disruption, potential glucose intolerance, possible DNA damage in animal models, environmental persistence, lacks essential nutrients

780.name: Nitrogen
780.description: Nitrogen is an inert, colorless, odorless gas often used in food packaging to displace oxygen, preventing spoilage and oxidation without directly interacting with the food or the body.

sources.label: PMC7268273 â Modified atmosphere packaging in food industry
PubMed â Packaging gases and their effect on food quality

780.benefits: Extends shelf life by reducing oxidation, prevents growth of aerobic spoilage bacteria

3.name: Potassium Bicarbonate
3.description: Potassium bicarbonate is an inorganic salt commonly used as a leavening agent in baking and as a source of potassium in food products. In the body, potassium helps maintain electrolyte balance, nerve transmission, and muscle function.

sources.label: PMC8761452 â Potassium Intake and Human Health
PubMed â Clinical use of bicarbonate in chronic kidney disease

3.risks: Hyperkalemia (in people with kidney dysfunction), gastrointestinal irritation (at high doses), potassium overdose (rare, usually in supplement form)
3.benefits: Electrolyte balance, may help reduce mild metabolic acidosis, supports nerve and muscle function

53.name: Magnesium Chloride
53.description: Magnesium chloride is an inorganic compound used as a dietary magnesium supplement and as a mineral fortifier in foods and beverages; magnesium is essential for enzyme function, nerve transmission, and muscle contraction.

sources.label: PubMed â Magnesium in prevention and therapy
PMC5452223 â Magnesium in human health and disease

53.risks: Gastrointestinal upset at high doses, diarrhea, hypermagnesemia (in those with renal impairment)
53.benefits: Corrects magnesium deficiency, supports cardiovascular health, aids neuromuscular function

600.name: organic pineapple juice concentrate
600.description: Organic pineapple juice concentrate is produced by removing water from pineapple juice made from organically grown pineapples, resulting in a sweet, shelf-stable ingredient commonly used in beverages and processed foods. It provides natural sugars, vitamin C, and some phytonutrients, but has less fiber than whole pineapple and a higher glycemic impact.

sources.label: ScienceDirect â Effects of concentration technology on quality of pineapple juice
PubMed â Nutritional and functional properties of pineapple

600.risks: High glycemic index, reduced fiber content, possible dental erosion, potential spike in blood sugar
600.benefits: Source of vitamin C, natural flavoring, contains some antioxidants

544.name: Fruit And Vegetable Juice
544.description: Fruit and vegetable juice refers to the liquid extracted from fruits and vegetables, often used for coloring or flavoring in processed foods. The nutrient profile and health effects depend on processing methods, with clarified or concentrated forms generally lacking fiber and some micronutrients compared to whole produce.

sources.label: PMC5872760 â Effect of fruit and vegetable juices on health
PubMed â Comparison of nutritional quality: juice vs. whole fruits/vegetables

544.risks: Loss of fiber, rapid sugar absorption, possible reduction in micronutrients due to processing
544.benefits: Source of vitamins and antioxidants depending on processing, natural coloring

547.name: Green Tea Extract
547.description: Green tea extract is a concentrated form of bioactive compounds, primarily catechins such as epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), derived from Camellia sinensis leaves and used for its antioxidant effects in supplements and health foods.

sources.label: Green tea (Camellia sinensis) and cancer prevention
Potential Adverse Effects of Green Tea Extracts

547.risks: Liver toxicity at high doses, gastrointestinal discomfort, potential drug interactions, possible insomnia due to caffeine content
547.benefits: Antioxidant activity, may support cardiovascular health, may aid in weight management, anti-inflammatory effects

1085.name: Niacinamide (Vitamin B3)
1085.description: Niacinamide, also known as nicotinamide, is a water-soluble form of vitamin B3 essential for energy metabolism and DNA repair in the body. It is commonly used in food fortification and supplements to support cellular health.

sources.label: PMC524396 â Role of niacin and niacinamide in nutrition and therapeutics
PubMed â Niacin and human health: The benefits and risks

1085.risks: Potential liver toxicity in extremely high doses, mild gastrointestinal discomfort in sensitive individuals, rare allergic reactions
1085.benefits: Supports energy metabolism, promotes DNA repair, may improve skin barrier function, helps prevent pellagra, supports nervous system function

1269.name: Biotin (Vitamin B7)
1269.description: Biotin, also known as vitamin B7, is a water-soluble B-vitamin that acts as a coenzyme in the metabolism of fatty acids, amino acids, and glucose, supporting normal energy production and cellular function.

sources.label: NIH Office of Dietary Supplements: Biotin Fact Sheet
NCBI: Biotin (Vitamin B7)

1269.risks: None at recommended doses, potential interference with laboratory tests at high supplemental doses
1269.benefits: Supports metabolism, essential for fatty acid synthesis, supports hair and nail health in deficiency, important for cell signaling

669.name: Gum Arabic (Organic Acacia)
669.description: Gum Arabic, derived from Acacia tree sap, is a natural soluble dietary fiber commonly used as a stabilizer, thickener, and emulsifier in food products. It is largely fermentable by gut microbiota and has minimal impact on taste or texture.

sources.label: PubMed â Health benefits of gum arabic
PMC5372979 â Functional properties of Acacia gum as dietary fiber

669.risks: Possible digestive discomfort at high doses, rare allergic reactions
669.benefits: Prebiotic effects, supports beneficial gut bacteria, increases dietary fiber intake, improves glycemic response

1061.name: Ester gum
